 COAGULOPATHY
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure:  Required urgent intubation on
   transfer secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).
    Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the alveolar pattern
   seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is vasculitis - Wegener's
   granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity.  No
   clear infiltrate is seen, although pneumonia is possible given
   prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   worsening leukocytosis. Given bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose
   steroids (on prednisone 40+mg PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely
   increased O2 requirement, concern for PCP as well. No hemodynamic
   compromise to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been
   bedbound for prolonged period.
   - vent set at A/C 480x14 (rate reduced secondary to
   metabolic/respiratory alkalosis), FiO2 50% (slowly downtitrating as
   tolerated), PEEP 8
   - continue 40mg IV Q8 hours
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - continue cytoxan, consent given by daughter
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage this AM showed red blood.  Platelets
   98 this AM, therefore mucosal bleed unlikely (although may have uremic
   platelets). Coagulopathic, as below.
   - Serial hct Q6 hours
   - Type and cross 2 units pRBCs
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 or concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated.
   - Steroid therapy, as above
   - Will discuss use of Cytoxan with renal
   - Renal recs
   - Avoiding renotoxic agents
   - Plasmaphresis on hold at this point per blood bank
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be nutritional
   given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to sample being
   drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still elevated to
   >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**];
   unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of OMR. Concern for
   DIC given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia as
   well.
   - Suspect if inhibitor is playing role that high dose steroids, Cytoxan
   should be of benefit
   - Add on fibrinogen, haptoglobin, FDP, fractionate bilirubin
   - Monitor DIC labs [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis with left-shift given high-dose
   steroids, although continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection -
   without productive cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient
   did present with uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of
   ciprofloxacin.
   - Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - BAL at time of bronchoscopy
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to start if she decompensates
   .
   #. Metabolic/respiratory alkalosis:  Likely secondary to tachypnea
   prior to intubation in addition to Bicitra (started for low bicarbonate
   secondary to renal dysfunction). Rate increased, Bicitra discontinued.
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  Blood pressure improved with intubation. Written for
   labetalol at this time.
   .
   #. Anemia:  At baseline since admission. Initially attributed to renal
   dysfunction. Several likely contributors currently, including DAH. Also
   with recent GI bleed. Also concern for DIC/hemolysis currently given
   hyperbilirubinemia, decreasing platelet count.
   - Checking DIC labs, as above
   - Smear to assess for schistocytes
   - Maintain hematocrit >25, giving one tranfusion pRBCs now
   .
   FEN:  Careful repletion of lytes given renal failure, NPO at this time
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots (avoiding all heparin products), PPI IV,
   bowel regimen PRN
   Access:  Pheresis catheter, PIV - may need CVL if any hemodynamic
   instability, A-line (for frequent ABGs)
   Code status:  FULL CODE, confirmed with patient's HCP
   Communication:  [**Name (NI) 747**] (daughter, HCP), ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7905**]
   Disposition:  ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Will start tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  SSI given high dose steroids
   Lines:
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2138-9-12**] 10:25 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2138-9-12**] 02:59 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Pneumoboots
 avoiding heparin products at this time
   Stress ulcer:  PPI IV
   VAP:  Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  [**Doctor First Name 747**] (daughter, HCP), ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7905**]
   Code status:  FULL CODE
   Disposition:  ICU for now
Summary:
The patient is a 97-year-old female with a history of hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis, now presenting with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the context of hemoptysis. The patient required urgent intubation due to fatigue and airway protection. Bronchoscopy showed diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, which correlates with the alveolar pattern seen on chest X-ray. The differential diagnosis includes vasculitis - Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity. There is also a concern for pneumonia, given prolonged hospitalization, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and worsening leukocytosis. Additionally, there is a concern for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) due to high-dose steroid use.

The patient has a history of gastritis, and GI bleed is also possible. OG lavage showed red blood, and the platelet count is low, suggesting mucosal bleeding. The patient is coagulopathic, as evidenced by an elevated INR and PTT. There is a concern for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia, and a positive inhibitor screen. 

The patient has leukocytosis with a left shift, expected due to high-dose steroids, but it continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection is present. Cultures have been obtained, and antibiotics will be

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension and glomerulonephritis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to fatigue and airway protection due to hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy showed diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, which correlates with the alveolar pattern seen on the chest X-ray. The patient also has an elevated white blood cell count, anemia, decreased platelet count, and hyperbilirubinemia. There is suspicion of pANCA vasculitis, possibly induced by hydralazine. The patient is currently on high-dose steroids and cyclophosphamide. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, requiring mechanical ventilation. There is concern for possible pneumonia or Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) given the prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression, and worsening oxygen requirements.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR and PTT, suggesting a coagulation disorder. This could be due to uremic platelets, coagulopathy associated with renal failure, or the presence of an inhibitor.
3. Glomerulonephritis: The patient has a history of glomerulonephritis and is suspected to have pANCA vasculitis, possibly induced by hydralazine. Steroid therapy and cyclophosphamide are

   Assessment and Plan

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure:  Required urgent intubation on
   transfer secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given
   hemoptysis).  Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the
   alveolar pattern seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is
   vasculitis - Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis
   given pANCA positivity.  No clear infiltrate is seen, although
   pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and worsening leukocytosis.
   Given bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone
   40+mg PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement,
   concern for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   - vent set to be changed to ARDS protocol, P/F ratio 208 this AM
   - recheck ABG after vent changes
   - continue 40mg IV Q8 hours
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - continue cytoxan, consent given by daughter
   - monitor hematocrit TID
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage this AM showed red blood.  Platelets
   98 this AM, but may have uremic platelets.  Pt is coagulopathic, as
   below.
   - check hematocrit TID
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated.
   - Steroid therapy, as above
   - continue cytoxan
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   - Plasmaphresis on hold at this point per blood bank
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be nutritional
   given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to sample being
   drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still elevated to
   >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**];
   unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of OMR. Concern for
   DIC given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia as
   well.
   - Suspect if inhibitor is playing role that high dose steroids, Cytoxan
   should be of benefit
   - Add on fibrinogen, haptoglobin, FDP, fractionate bilirubin
   - DIC labs normal today, check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if
   abnormal
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis with left-shift given high-dose
   steroids, although continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection -
   without productive cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient
   did present with uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of
   ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to start if she decompensates
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  Blood pressure high in the 180s this AM in setting of
   bradycardia.  Given transient PTT of 150, consider intracranial bleed.
   Decrease of propofol resulted some improval of heart rate.
   - head CT today
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   .
   #. Anemia:  transfused 2 units pRBCs yesterday.  Several likely
   contributors, gastritis, DAH.  Also concern for DIC/hemolysis currently
   given hyperbilirubinemia, decreasing platelet count.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Nutrition
 nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   FEN:  Careful repletion of lytes given renal failure, plan to start
   tube feed
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots (avoiding all heparin products), PPI IV,
   bowel regimen PRN
   Access:  Pheresis catheter, PIV - may need CVL if any hemodynamic
   instability, A-line (for frequent ABGs)
   Code status:  FULL CODE, confirmed with patient's HCP

   Disposition:  ICU for now

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, coagulopathy, glomerulonephritis, and potential lower gastrointestinal bleeding. 

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions are:
1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): Given the diffuse alveolar hemorrhage seen on bronchoscopy and the bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, there is a possibility of developing ARDS. The patient is already intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
2. Pulmonary embolism: Although there is no evidence of hemodynamic compromise, the patient has been bedbound for a prolonged period, which increases the risk of developing pulmonary embolism.
3. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP): High-dose steroids have been given, which can increase the risk of opportunistic infections like PCP. The presence of bilateral patchy opacities on the chest X-ray raises suspicion for PCP.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastritis and hemoptysis, which could be due to gastrointestinal bleeding. The use of PPI IV is appropriate to reduce the risk of further bleeding.

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of pulmonary-renal syndrome, positive p-ANCA, and possible hydralazine-induced vasculitis. She was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The patient has multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, acute renal failure, leukocytosis, gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, and bradycardia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is complicated by DAH in the context of pulmonary-renal syndrome and p-ANCA positive vasculitis. This is further complicated by uremic platelets and thrombocytopenia. There is a possibility of pulmonary infection, but it is difficult to assess due to diffuse bilateral infiltrates. A bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) has been performed to rule out infection. Continuing ventilator support with ARDS net TVs and adjusting the mode to optimize pH is recommended. Steroids and cyclophosphamide therapy should be continued.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure associated with p-ANCA positive vasculitis, likely microscopic polyangiitis. Possibility of hydralazine-induced vasculitis cannot be ruled out. Continuous hemodialysis (HD) should be continued. Solumedrol and cyc

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis,
   improved from yesterday.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Pt changed to AC ARDS NET
   protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F ratio of 208. Pt on
   spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today. Tried on PSV 8/5 this AM
   and did well. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).
   Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the alveolar pattern
   seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is vasculitis - Wegener's
   granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity.
   Pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis. Given
   bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone 40+mg
   PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement, concern
   for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   -Check ABG on PSV
 if ok, will wean PSV to [**5-20**]. Perhaps will do SBT
   today if pt tolerates PSV well with possible extubation today or
   tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage without output now. Decreasing
   amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis yesterday for fluid overload
   per Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   -Possible plasmapheresis
 will f/u with blood bank
   - f/u renal recs and t/b re: next plan for dialysis.
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission but 1.1 today with PTT
   33.1. Unlikely to be nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT
   suspected secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent
   pheresis line, although still elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of
   note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being
   inhibited by review of OMR. DIC labs nl. Heparin products stopped and
   platelets now rising, concerning for HITT.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   -f/u HITT antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis given high-dose steroids,
   stable. No clear evidence of infection - without productive cough,
   abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient did present with
   uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to treat for VAP or HAP if she
   decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol, will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions yesterday. Several
   likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow
   -Will t/b with family re: goals of care and pt
s improvement
   -Will defer palliative care c/s at this time.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2138-9-14**] 02:38 AM 10 mL/hour; TFs held this
   AM for possible extubation
   Glycemic Control:  ISS given high dose steroids

 avoiding heparin products at this time

   Disposition:  ICU for now
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of glomerulonephritis, hypertension, and acute hypoxic respiratory failure. She is currently intubated and on ARDS NET protocol due to bilateral infiltrates on CXR and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 208. The patient was initially requiring urgent intubation secondary to fatigue and airway protection due to hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy showed diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), which correlates with the alveolar pattern seen on CXR. The differential diagnosis includes vasculitis (Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis), given pANCA positivity, pneumonia, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary embolism.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has improved today and tried on pressure support ventilation (PSV) 8/5 this morning and did well. Goal is to wean PSV to 5-20 and possibly perform a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) today if the patient tolerates PSV well, with possible extubation today or tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
2. Hemoptysis: DAH seen on bronchoscopy. Given the history of gastritis, gastrointestinal (GI) bleed is also possible. OG lavage without output now. Decreasing amounts of old

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, admitted for glomerulonephritis, now presenting with acute hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to fatigue and airway protection due to hemoptysis. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. She has been diagnosed with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), which correlates with the alveolar pattern seen on chest X-ray. The differential diagnosis includes vasculitis such as Wegener's granulomatosis and microscopic polyangiitis given positive pANCA. No clear infiltrate is seen, although pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and worsening leukocytosis.

The patient's current condition includes acute hypoxic respiratory failure, hemoptysis with DAH seen on bronchoscopy, glomerulonephritis suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis, coagulopathy with elevated INR and PTT, leukocytosis, potential lower gastrointestinal bleed, hypertension, and anemia. The patient has received high-dose steroids and cyclophosphamide therapy for her conditions. The patient's family has been consulted for palliative care due to her poor prognosis, and a nutrition consult has been ordered for tube feeding.

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of renal pulmonary syndrome, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. She has been admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure in the setting of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The patient's conditions include acute respiratory failure, pulmonary-renal syndrome, acute renal failure, leukocytosis, gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, coagulopathy, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has shown improvement in oxygenation but still requires ventilatory support. The underlying cause of respiratory failure is pulmonary-renal syndrome, which may be due to p-ANCA positive vasculitis, possibly induced by hydralazine. Monitoring and optimizing respiratory support, such as weaning off the ventilator, will be crucial.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be a result of the underlying vasculitis. Treatment includes hemodialysis and immunosuppressive therapy with steroids and cyclophosphamide. Close monitoring of renal function and fluid balance is essential.

3. Coagulopathy: The patient exhibits elevated PTT and a positive inhibitor screen, indicating the presence of a clotting factor inhibitor. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the coagulopathy, and appropriate management should be implemented to prevent further bleeding complications.

4. Thromboc

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in the setting of renal pulmonary syndrome, acute renal failure (ARF), and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). She has been admitted to the ICU and has been receiving various treatments including mechanical ventilation, hemodialysis, antibiotics, steroids, and cytoxan.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to pulmonary-renal syndrome/p-ANCA vasculitis, uremic platelets, and thrombocytopenia. There is a concern for possible infection, but this needs to be ruled out through bronchoscopy and BAL.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has ARF, which is likely due to p-ANCA positive vasculitis, possibly microscopic polyangiitis or hydralazine-induced vasculitis. She is currently on hemodialysis and will continue with this treatment.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which could be related to the use of steroids. There is no obvious infectious etiology, but broad-spectrum antibiotics may be considered if there is clinical decline.

4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding (GIB): The patient has GIB with heme-positive stool, possibly due to gastritis. NG lavage was negative, suggesting that the bleeding might be from swallowed hemoptysis. Monitoring for evidence of GI

   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be hydralazine p-ANCA induced
   vasculitis.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary
   to hydralazine induced p anca vasculitis.  Differential includes
   Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA
   positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged
   hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   leukocytosis. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).  Pt
   changed to AC ARDS NET protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F
   ratio of 208. Pt on spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today.
   Patient currently on CPAP/PSV 8/5 doing well. No hemodynamic compromise
   to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been bedbound for
   prolonged period.

 if ok, will wean PSV to [**5-20**]. Perhaps will do SBT

   pending her clinical status and oxygenation.

   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding

   .

   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although

 will f/u with blood bank

   33.1. Unlikely to be nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT
   suspected secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent
   pheresis line, although still elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension and glomerulonephritis, who is currently in the ICU due to acute hypoxic respiratory failure caused by diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) thought to be induced by hydralazine-associated p-ANCA vasculitis. The patient has been intubated and placed on CPAP/PSV 8/5, with an ABG showing pH 7.50, PaCO2 36, SaO2 82%, and Hct 28. The patient is expected to have a SBT today with possible extubation tomorrow, pending her clinical status and oxygenation.

The patient's medical history includes gastritis, which could potentially lead to gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient has also experienced hemoptysis, likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off clotting factors. There is a concern for active bleeding with a goal Hct >25.

The patient has glomerulonephritis, suspected to be hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. She underwent a renal biopsy on 9/1, which showed "marked chronic vascular disease" and surprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although pANCA level markedly elevated. The patient requires dialysis today for fluid overload per renal. The plan includes steroid therapy and cytoxan, as well as plasmapheresis this PM.

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of glomerulonephritis, hypertension, and recent acute hypoxic respiratory failure. She was initially intubated due to fatigue and airway protection secondary to hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy showed diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), which correlates with the alveolar pattern seen on chest X-ray. The differential diagnosis includes vasculitis (Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis) given pANCA positivity, pneumonia, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP).

The patient has been on high-dose steroids (prednisone 40 mg PO daily) since August 30th. There is concern for PCP given the prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression, and leukocytosis. No hemodynamic compromise suggests pulmonary embolism is unlikely, although the patient has been bedbound for a prolonged period.

The patient's current condition includes:
- Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has improved from yesterday and is now on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 0.4. She may undergo a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) today if she tolerates CPAP well, with possible extubation today or tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
- Hemoptysis: DAH seen on bronchoscopy. There is also a possibility of gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding due to a history of gastritis

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with acute respiratory failure due to pulmonary-renal syndrome (p-ANCA + vasculitis). She is also experiencing dialysis-associated hypotension, uremic platelets, and thrombocytopenia. The patient has a history of hypertension, anemia, coagulopathy, and leukocytosis. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. Her vital signs include a heart rate of 61 bpm, blood pressure of 165/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and temperature of 36.7°C. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, creatinine, lactate, LDH, and D-dimer levels. Imaging reveals slight increases in effusions and aspergilli on both sides.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if the underlying pulmonary-renal syndrome is not effectively managed.
2. Infection: Despite negative microbiology results, the patient is at high risk for developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation and immunosuppression.
3. Bleeding: Recurrent bleeding from the endotracheal tube suggests a risk of further hemorrhage.

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be hydralazine p-ANCA induced
   vasculitis.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary
   to hydralazine induced p anca vasculitis.  Differential includes
   Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA
   positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged
   hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   leukocytosis. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).  Pt
   changed to AC ARDS NET protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F
   ratio of 208. Pt on spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today.
   Patient currently on CPAP/PSV 8/5 doing well. No hemodynamic compromise
   to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been bedbound for
   prolonged period.
   - wean FiO2 to 50%, check ABG.
   - if ABG ok, then will try SBT today. If not able to wean today, will
   attempt tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit daily
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   - transfuse plasma
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis today for fluid overload per
   Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   - continue plasmapheresis
 2 more sessions
   - continue dialysis
   - get tunneled line today by IR
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   # Positive HIT antibody: Given positive HIT, pt has risk of thrombosis,
   especially given her systemic inflammation in the setting of
   vasculitis.
   -  consider argatroban
   .
   # Metabolic alkalosis: question if dialysate containes more bicarb than
   usual.
   - touch base with renal
   - continue to monitor acid-base status
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  resolved. INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be
   nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to
   sample being drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still
   elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen
   positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of
   OMR. DIC labs nl. Heparin products stopped and platelets now rising,
   concerning for HITT.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   - f/u HIT antibody
   -d/c antiplatelet antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis given high-dose steroids,
   stable. No clear evidence of infection - without productive cough,
   abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient did present with
   uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to treat for VAP or HAP if she
   decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**]. Most
   likely in the setting of swallowing coughed-up blood. Suspected to be
   diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol (SBP>160), will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions for the past few days.
   Several likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse if hematocrit <25
   - daily CBC
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow
   -Will t/b with family re: goals of care and pt
s improvement
   -Will defer palliative care c/s at this time.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, glomerulonephritis, and acute hypoxic respiratory failure due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The patient also has a positive pANCA, which suggests a possible diagnosis of hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis or other types of vasculitis such as Wegener's granulomatosis or microscopic polyangiitis.

The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV 8/5 and is doing well without any hemodynamic compromise, suggesting that pulmonary embolism is less likely. However, the patient has been bedbound for a prolonged period, so it is important to monitor for any signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and consider prophylactic measures such as pneumoboots.

The patient's recent laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.7, which could be due to high-dose steroid therapy. The patient's platelet count is also decreasing, which may be related to the positive HIT antibody detected in the lab results.

The patient's coagulopathy has resolved, but there is a history of an inhibitor screen positive on [**2138-8-26**], indicating a potential coagulation disorder. The patient's INR is elevated, and the PTT is still above normal levels, suggesting ongoing coagulation issues.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension and glomerulonephritis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, which is believed to be secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) caused by hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. The patient also has anemia, leukocytosis, coagulopathy, lower gastrointestinal bleed, and hypertension.

The patient underwent plasmapheresis on [**9-15**] with 9 bags of fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Rheumatology recommendations include increasing cyclophosphamide (be wary of hemorrhagic cystitis and leukopenia). The patient restarted tube feeds, with plans to hold at midnight in case of extubation. PF4 antibody has been ordered.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 149/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on 60% FiO2. She is on CPAP/PSV 8/5 and is doing well without any hemodynamic compromise suggesting pulmonary embolism. The patient's ABG on PSV is pending, and she may be weaned to 5-20 PSV with a possible spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) today

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of acute renal failure and glomerulonephritis in the setting of pulmonary-renal syndrome (p-ANCA + vasculitis). She is currently experiencing acute hypoxemic respiratory failure secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 69 bpm, blood pressure of 157/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. 

She is receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 320 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 76.

   [**Age over 90 **] yo F w/ ARF/GN in setting of pulm-renal syndrome (p-anca +

   Acute resp failure [**2-17**] DAH in context of pulmonary-renal syndrome
   [p-anca + vasculitis (Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic
   polyangiitis vs hydral-induced vasculitis).  Further confounded by
   uremic platelets and thrombocytopenia. Also with component of fluid
   o/l/effusions in setting of renal failure. Infection appears less
   likely, though pna is difficult to assess in setting of diffuse b/l
   infiltrates and with ongoing intubation and immunsupression she is at
   high risk for developing a VAP.  She is s/p bronch with BAL to r/o
   initial infection and we continue to follow imaging and clinical status
   closely.  She is doing well on little vent support, but at present the
   main barriers to extubation are her poor cough and frequent sx
   requirements.
   Agree with plan to continue PS ventilation.  Recheck abg on 40% fio2
   and consider moving toward SBT as we reevaluate her suction needs. We
   continue cytoxan, steroids and phoresis with rheum, renal, and
   transfusion service input appreciated.  Will continue PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**]
   (pentamidine).   She continues with HD for clearance and volume
   removal.  Tunnel HD catheter scheduled for IR placement today.  Has
   metabolic alkalosis and appears comfortable on vent.  Likely [**2-17**]
   dialysate with HD.  Will touch base with renal regarding changes to
   optimize Ph.
   She continues to have a leukocytosis (down slightly), in the setting of
   steroids, with no obvious infectious etiology. We follow pending micro,
   and will initiate empiric broad antibx in setting of clinical decline
   as above or overt change in secretions or imaging.
   Her plts have improved after significant drop, concerning for HIT. We
   continue to hold all heparin products.  HIT antibody pending.
   H/o htn at baseline.  We are holding meds while sedated and undergoing
   HD.  Continue to assess for restarting with conservative BP
   parameters.
   Will continue to update family and address goals of care, working with
   renal/rheum services to provide information regarding prognosis.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TFs on hold, will resume pending reassessment for
   extubation.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with pulmonary-renal syndrome, respiratory failure, acute hypoxemic respiratory failure due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), and p-ANCA positive vasculitis. She has a history of hypertension, anemia, leukocytosis, coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, and fluid overload. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with PS ventilation mode. She has been receiving plasmapheresis, increased dose of cytoxin, and antibiotics. The patient's condition is complicated by potential ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and the need for hemodialysis (HD) for clearance and volume removal. She also has metabolic alkalosis and her platelets have improved after a significant drop, concerning for HIT. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, development of VAP, further decline in renal function, bleeding complications due to coagulopathy, and potential infections due to immunosuppression.

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be hydralazine p-ANCA induced
   vasculitis.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary
   to hydralazine induced p anca vasculitis.  Differential includes
   Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA
   positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged
   hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   leukocytosis. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).  Pt
   changed to AC ARDS NET protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F
   ratio of 208. Pt on spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today.
   Patient currently on CPAP/PSV 8/5 doing well. No hemodynamic compromise
   to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been bedbound for
   prolonged period.
   - wean FiO2 to 50%, check ABG.
   - if ABG ok, then will try SBT today. If not able to wean today, will
   attempt tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit daily
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   - transfuse plasma
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis today for fluid overload per
   Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   - continue plasmapheresis
 2 more sessions
   - continue dialysis
   - get tunneled line today by IR
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   # Positive HIT antibody: Given positive HIT, pt has risk of thrombosis,
   especially given her systemic inflammation in the setting of
   vasculitis.
   -  consider argatroban
   .
   # Metabolic alkalosis: question if dialysate containes more bicarb than
   usual.
   - touch base with renal
   - continue to monitor acid-base status
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  resolved. INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be
   nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to
   sample being drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still
   elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen
   positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of
   OMR. DIC labs nl. Heparin products stopped and platelets now rising,
   concerning for HITT.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   - f/u HIT antibody
   -d/c antiplatelet antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis given high-dose steroids,
   stable. No clear evidence of infection - without productive cough,
   abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient did present with
   uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to treat for VAP or HAP if she
   decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**]. Most
   likely in the setting of swallowing coughed-up blood. Suspected to be
   diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol (SBP>160), will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions for the past few days.
   Several likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse if hematocrit <25
   - daily CBC
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow
   -Will t/b with family re: goals of care and pt
s improvement
   -Will defer palliative care c/s at this time.

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of glomerulonephritis, admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. She is currently intubated on CPAP/PSV 8/5 and showing improvement. She has positive HIT antibodies, renal insufficiency requiring dialysis, anemia, leukocytosis, and potential metabolic alkalosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to DAH secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. Pneumonia, including Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), is also a possibility given her prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis.
2. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient may have metabolic alkalosis, possibly due to the dialysate containing more bicarbonate than usual.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient initially had an elevated INR and PTT, suggesting coagulopathy. However, this has resolved, and she is now showing signs of HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia).
4. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which is expected with high-dose steroids. However, there is no clear evidence

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be hydralazine p-ANCA induced
   vasculitis.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary
   to hydralazine induced p anca vasculitis.  Differential includes
   Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA
   positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged
   hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   leukocytosis. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).  Pt
   changed to AC ARDS NET protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F
   ratio of 208. Pt on spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today.
   Patient currently on CPAP/PSV 5/5 FiO2 40% doing well. No hemodynamic
   compromise to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been
   bedbound for prolonged period and is now at increased risk for
   thrombosis bc of HIT.
   - will try SBT today and possible extubation later today after
   procedure
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit daily
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   - transfuse plasma
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis today for fluid overload per
   Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   - continue plasmapheresis
 2 more sessions
   - continue HD
   - get tunneled line today by IR
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   # Positive HIT antibody: Given positive HIT, pt has risk of thrombosis,
   especially given her systemic inflammation in the setting of
   vasculitis.
   - although at inc risk for thrombosis, not a candidate for
   anti-coagulation given DAH
   - monitor closely for signs of DVT/PE
   .
   # Metabolic alkalosis: question if dialysate contains more bicarb than
   usual.
   - continue to monitor acid-base status
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  resolved. INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be
   nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to
   sample being drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still
   elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen
   positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of
   OMR. DIC labs nl. HIT Ab positive.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   - is positive for HIT antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Resolved. Patient did present with uncomplicated UTI
   and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - Hold off on antibiotics for now, low threshold to treat for VAP or
   HAP if she decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol (SBP>160), will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions for the past few days.
   Several likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse if hematocrit <25
   - daily CBC
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow
   -Will t/b with family re: goals of care and pt
s improvement
   -Will defer palliative care c/s at this time.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  5U glargine qhs, ISS
   Lines:
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2138-9-12**] 10:25 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2138-9-12**] 09:39 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots for DVT ppx
   Stress ulcer:  on Pantoprazole 40 mg IV Q24H
   VAP:  bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU for now

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension and glomerulonephritis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the context of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), which is thought to be hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. 

The patient's current condition is stable, with improved oxygenation and reduced secretions. She is on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 40% and doing well. The plan is to attempt a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) today and consider extubation later if successful. 

The patient has positive HIT antibodies and is at increased risk for thrombosis. However, she is not a candidate for anticoagulation due to ongoing DAH. 

Her metabolic alkalosis is being monitored, and coagulopathy has resolved. 

There are multiple ongoing concerns and plans for the patient, including ongoing treatment for glomerulonephritis, monitoring for signs of deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism, close glucose monitoring, and follow-up with rheumatology and renal teams. 

Overall, the patient's condition has improved, and there are plans for potential extubation and further management of her underlying conditions.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 90-year-old female with acute renal failure and glomerulonephritis in the setting of pulmonary-renal syndrome (p-ANCA positive vasculitis).
- The patient has experienced acute hypoxemic respiratory failure secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH).
- The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 84 bpm and blood pressure ranging from 139/64 mmHg to 179/75 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is at 98%.
- The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation support with CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 311 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 40%.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, creatinine, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and D-dimer levels. Platelet count is low, and there is evidence of metabolic alkalosis.
- Imaging shows effusions in both lungs, with some improvement in clearing.
- The patient has a positive HIT antibody, indicating a heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) diagnosis. Heparin products are being withheld.
- The patient's medical history includes hypertension, allergies to sulfonamides, macrodantin,

   or overt change in secretions or imaging.

   continue to hold all heparin products.

   HD.  Continue to assess for restarting with conservative BP
   parameters.
   Glargine added to SSI for hyperglycemia control in setting of steroids.
   Will continue to update family and address goals of care, working with
   renal/rheum services to provide information regarding prognosis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with pulmonary-renal syndrome, acute respiratory failure, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. She has a history of p-ANCA positive vasculitis and is currently on hemodialysis for renal failure. The patient's condition includes respiratory failure, hypoxemia, leukocytosis, anemia, thrombocytopenia (HIT+), metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration. Close monitoring and appropriate ventilatory support are necessary.
2. Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome: The patient's underlying condition may progress, leading to worsening renal function and pulmonary involvement.
3. Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage: Continued bleeding in the lungs can cause hypoxemia and respiratory distress. Frequent suctioning of secretions and monitoring of oxygenation parameters are required.
4. Thrombocytopenia (HIT+): The patient's platelet count is low, and she has tested positive for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This condition increases the risk of thrombosis. Close monitoring for signs of thrombosis is essential, and all heparin products should be held.
5. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which may require adjustment of dialysate

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, admitted for glomerulonephritis, now presenting with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the context of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The DAH is suspected to be secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. 

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to DAH secondary to pulmonary-renal syndrome, suspected to be hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. Other possible causes include pneumonia (including Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia) due to prolonged hospitalization, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis. The patient has been successfully extubated.

The patient's hemoptysis is likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off clotting factors. There is also a possibility of GI bleed due to her history of gastritis. The hematocrit is stable, and she is receiving high-dose steroids and PPI IV.

The patient has glomerulonephritis suspected to be hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. She had a renal biopsy showing "marked chronic vascular disease" and no evidence of vasculitis, although pANCA levels were markedly elevated. Dialysis was performed today for fluid overload per Renal.

There are possible signs of a urinary tract infection (UTI), and she is awaiting urine culture. She has

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be secondary to hydralazine p-ANCA
   induced vasculitis.
   #. Acute respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary to
   pulmonary-renal syndrome (positive p anca, vasculitis) suspected to be
   hydralazine induced p anca vasculitis.  Differential also includes
   Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA
   positivity.  Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged
   hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   leukocytosis. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).  Pt
   changed to AC ARDS NET protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F
   ratio of 208. Pt on spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today.
   Patient currently on CPAP/PSV 5/5 FiO2 40% doing well. No hemodynamic
   compromise to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been
   bedbound for prolonged period and is now at increased risk for
   thrombosis bc of HIT.
   - follow up ABG
   -secretions appear to be continuing
   - will try SBT today and possible extubation later today after
   procedure
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - continue PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close
   glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit daily
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   - PT, Speech and swallow ordered.
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   - transfuse plasma
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis today for fluid overload per
   Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   - continue plasmapheresis
 1 more session on Friday
   - continue HD
   - get tunneled line yesterday by IR
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   # Possible UTI:  wbcs, bacteria, and few yeast seen on u/a.  Will await
   urine culture.  Consider starting diflucan for yeasts.
   # Positive HIT antibody: Given positive HIT, pt has risk of thrombosis,
   especially given her systemic inflammation in the setting of
   vasculitis.
   - although at inc risk for thrombosis, not a candidate for
   anti-coagulation given DAH
   - monitor closely for signs of DVT/PE
   .
   # Metabolic alkalosis: renal decreasing bicarb conc in diasylate
   - continue to monitor acid-base status
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  resolved. INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be
   nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to
   sample being drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still
   elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen

   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal

   #. Leukocytosis:  Resolved. Patient did present with uncomplicated UTI
   and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - Hold off on antibiotics for now, low threshold to treat for VAP or
   HAP if she decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol (SBP>160), will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions for the past few days.

   - daily CBC

The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, currently admitted with glomerulonephritis and acute hypoxic respiratory failure due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The DAH is suspected to be secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. The patient also has a positive pANCA, making differential diagnoses of Wegener's granulomatosis or microscopic polyangiitis possible. She is currently on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 40% and showing improvement. Other conditions include hemoptysis, glomerulonephritis, possible UTI, metabolic alkalosis, coagulopathy, leukocytosis, hypertension, anemia, and positive HIT antibody.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further due to ongoing DAH or development of pneumonia.
2. Pulmonary embolism: Given the patient's prolonged bedbound status and positive HIT antibody, there is an increased risk of thrombosis, including pulmonary embolism.
3. GI bleed: Hemoptysis could be due to DAH or gastritis-induced GI bleed, which may require close monitoring and intervention.
4. UTI: The presence of WBCs, bacteria, and yeast in the urine analysis suggests a possible urinary tract infection, which should be treated appropriately.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with hypertension and glomerulonephritis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the context of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), which is suspected to be secondary to hydralazine p-ANCA induced vasculitis.

The patient's current medical conditions include:
1. Acute respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary to pulmonary-renal syndrome (positive p anca, vasculitis). Differential also includes Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis.
2. Hemoptysis: Likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
3. Glomerulonephritis: Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. Patient with renal biopsy on [date] which showed'marked chronic vascular disease' and surprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although pANCA level markedly elevated.
4. Positive HIT antibody: Given positive HIT, pt has risk of thrombosis, especially given her systemic inflammation in the setting of vasculitis.
5. Metabolic alkalosis: Renal decreasing bicarb conc in dialysate.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications. Here is a summary of the patient's condition:

- The patient underwent hemodialysis (HD) and pheresis, which led to hypertension but was later managed.
- An arterial blood gas (ABG) revealed a pH of 7.54, indicating alkalosis. The pCO2 was 39, which is within the normal range, while the pO2 was 107, indicating adequate oxygenation. The HCO3 level was 34, suggesting metabolic alkalosis.
- The physician decided to perform a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and extubate the patient in the morning due to it being too late in the day.
- Tube feeds were held overnight for extubation.
- Renal recommendations include decreasing HCO3 to 30 during HD today and administering epo 4000U with HD. Additionally, AlOH TID x 2 days is prescribed because of elevated pH.
- Rheumatology recommendations involve continuing Cytoxan and steroids, as they usually take 7-10 days before leukopenia is noted.
- Blood sugars have been in the low 150-200 range, so 5U Lantus qhs was added.
- Blood pressures have been in the 135-155 range, so no home labetalol is needed.
- The patient has allergies to sulfonamides, Macrodn

Summary:
The patient is a 92-year-old female with a chief complaint of pulmonary-renal syndrome, respiratory failure in the setting of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The patient has been diagnosed with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and is currently extubated. Other issues include pulmonary renal syndrome (DAH, acute renal failure, p-ANCA positive glomerulonephritis), leukocytosis, anemia, thrombocytopenia, HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia), metabolic alkalosis, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable due to acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. Monitoring and supportive care will be required to maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome: This condition involves inflammation of both the lungs and kidneys. It can lead to worsening respiratory and renal function, potentially requiring more aggressive interventions such as mechanical ventilation or dialysis.
3. Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT): The patient has tested positive for HIT, which is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by an immune response to heparin leading to low platelet counts. Alternative anticoagulation strategies will be necessary to prevent thrombotic complications.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, increasing the risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of HIT.

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be secondary to hydralazine p-ANCA
   induced vasculitis.
   #. Acute respiratory failure: Successfully extubated. The respiratory
   failure most likely due to DAH secondary to pulmonary-renal syndrome
   (positive p anca, vasculitis) suspected to be hydralazine induced p
   anca vasculitis.  Differential also includes Wegener's granulomatosis
   vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity.  Pneumonia
   (including PCP) is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis.  Patient
   successfully extubated this AM.
   - daily ABG
   - continue nebs
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - last session plasmapharesis today
   - HD for volume removal
   - continue PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close
   glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit daily
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   - f/u PT, Speech and swallow
   - PICC consult and then d/c CVL
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - hematocrit stable
   - PPI IV given known gastritis
   - treat DAH as above
   - Goal hct>25
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:   tunneled line in place. Etiology:
   hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. Patient with renal biopsy on
   [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic vascular disease' and suprisingly
   no evidence of vasculitis, although pANCA level markedly elevated.
   Dialysis for fluid overload per Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   - continue plasmapheresis
 1 more session today
   - continue HD with tunneled line
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   # Possible UTI:  wbcs, bacteria, and few yeast seen on u/a.
   - f/u urine culture.
   - Consider starting diflucan for yeasts.
   .
   # Metabolic alkalosis: renal decreasing bicarb conc in diasylate
   - continue to monitor acid-base status
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.
   - BP elevated (SBP>180), labetolol restarted PRN > 180.
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions for the past few days.
   Several likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable. Fe
   studies consistent with anemia of inflammation, not surprising given
   her inflammatory status.
   - transfuse if hematocrit <25
   - daily CBC
   .
   # HIT positivity: Given positive HIT, pt has risk of thrombosis,
   especially given her systemic inflammation in the setting of
   vasculitis.
   - although at inc risk for thrombosis, not a candidate for
   anti-coagulation given DAH
   - monitor closely for signs of DVT/PE
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Resolved. Patient did present with uncomplicated UTI
   and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - Hold off on antibiotics for now, low threshold to treat for VAP or
   HAP if she decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Tubefeeding: Novasource Renal Full strength
   Glycemic Control:  5U glargine qhs, ISS

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension and glomerulonephritis who was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the context of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The DAH is thought to be secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Acute respiratory failure due to DAH secondary to pulmonary-renal syndrome, which could be induced by hydralazine p-ANCA vasculitis. Differential also includes Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is also possible due to prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis.
2. Hemoptysis likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off clotting factors. GI bleed could also be possible given history of gastritis.
3. Glomerulonephritis with tunneled line in place. Etiology: hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. Patient with renal biopsy showing marked chronic vascular disease and no evidence of vasculitis, although pANCA level markedly elevated.
4. Possible urinary tract infection (UTI) with white blood cells, bacteria, and few yeast seen on urinalysis.
5. Metabolic alkalosis: renal decreasing bic

 goal 4 liter negative today

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with hypertension and glomerulonephritis who was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) suspected to be secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient is at risk of developing further respiratory failure due to ongoing pulmonary-renal syndrome, potential pneumonia (including PCP), and prolonged hospitalization.
2. Hemoptysis: The patient is likely to continue experiencing hemoptysis due to ongoing DAH and the presence of clotting factors in the blood. Monitoring hematocrit levels is important to assess for ongoing bleeding.
3. Glomerulonephritis: The patient has a history of glomerulonephritis, and the etiology is hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. Steroid therapy and cytoxan are recommended, and close follow-up with renal specialists is necessary.
4. Delirium: The patient may experience delirium, possibly due to sundowning. Haloperidol can be used as needed.
5. Possible UTI: The patient may have a urinary tract infection, which requires further evaluation and treatment based on urine culture results.
6. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient is at risk of developing metabolic alkalosis, especially if bicarbonate levels continue to decrease

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with acute respiratory failure secondary to pulmonary-renal syndrome (p-ANCA positive vasculitis) and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The patient has been experiencing multiple medical complications including leukocytosis, anemia, thrombocytopenia, metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and agitation/delirium.

The patient is currently doing well post-extubation with minimal oxygen requirements. She is receiving nebulizer treatments and continues to be on cyclophosphamide (cytoxan), steroids (to be changed to oral pending swallow evaluation), and plasmapheresis (last run) with input from rheumatology, nephrology, and transfusion services. The patient is also being treated with pentamidine for PCP and hemodialysis (HD) for clearance and volume removal.

The patient's white blood cell count is decreasing, but it is unclear if this is related to cytoxan or not. The healthcare team will monitor the patient closely for any signs of clinical decline or overt change in secretions or imaging, as there is a risk of opportunistic infections due to immunosuppression. The patient has tested positive for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), and all heparin products have been withheld. The patient will be closely monitored for the development of thrombosis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of ANCA-associated vasculitis, pulmonary-renal syndrome, and acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. She has been admitted to the ICU due to her condition. 

The patient has been receiving invasive ventilation but is now extubated and doing well on non-invasive oxygen. She was delirious and agitated overnight, so haloperidol was given for sedation. 

The patient has a history of allergies to sulfonamides, macrodantin, codeine, norvasc, hydralazine, and heparin agents. 

Her vital signs include a temperature of 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate of 63 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 124/55 mmHg to 201/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. 

The patient's physical examination shows that she is awake and alert, with clear lungs and no edema or rash. 

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.1 g/dL, platelet count of 111 K/uL, creatinine of 2.8 mg/dL, blood glucose of 141 mg/dL, sodium of 124 mEq/L, potassium of 4.4 mEq/L, chloride of 27 mEq/L, and calcium of 8.5 mg/dL. 

Assessment and Plan:
- Pulmonary-renal syndrome (DAH, ARF, p-anca + GN felt hydralazine-induced vasculitis)
- Leukocytosis
- Anemia
- Thrombocytopenia, HIT +
- Metabolic alkalosis
- Hypertension
- Agitation/delirium at night --> resolved now

The patient is doing well post-extubation with minimal oxygen requirements. She will continue with nebulizers and medications such as cyclophosphamide, steroids (to be changed to oral pending swallow evaluation), and plasmapheresis. The medical team is awaiting a swallow evaluation to determine if she can tolerate oral medications. 

Her white blood cell count continues to decrease, and her hemoglobin level is also low. The patient has a positive HIT antibody and is not a candidate for argatroban. Heparin products have been withheld, and the patient will be monitored for thrombosis. 

The patient's anemia is likely related to the pulmonary-renal syndrome, and she will receive epo with HD (hemodialysis) and be transfused for Hct < 21 or evidence of bleeding. 

The patient's hypertension is being managed with labetalol. 

The patient's agitation/delirium at night has been addressed, and she is now appropriate. Haloperidol or risperid
